prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We will measure the CO lines and the continuum in one Science Goal. We will use two FDM spectral windows for the CO line observations. The 2-1 transitions of 13^CO and C^18O lines will be measured in a single baseband with the coarsest channel spacing of 976.6kHz (1.33km/s). The 12^CO line will be observed in another FDM window with a channel spacing of 244.14kHz (~0.32 km/s). Since these disks have never been spatially resolved therefore we cannot reliably estimate the shape and width of the possible CO spectral line (in the course of sensitivity estimates we assumed a linewidth of 10km/s). The requested 0.32 km/s velocity resolution enable us to resolve the line and study the gas kinematics even in disk orientation close to face-on, when the line width would be ~2-3 km/s. For the continuum observation, we define two wide bandwidth TDM spectral windows, giving a 3.75 GHz total bandwidth. The line free regions of the FDM observations will also be added to the continuum data increasing the aggregate bandwidth to ~6.09GHz in total.

The data rate is high in this setup, but to fulfill our scientific aims we need to observe all three lines whose distances in frequency means that they can only be observed in two different basebands.

Based on our models we predicted a disk size of ~0.4 and 0.8 arcsec for HD 121191 and HD 121617, respectively (see Preparatory work). In the case of HD 121191 we primarily focus on gas detection and do not plan to resolve the sources. HD 121617 is expected to be marginally resolved with our planned spatial resolution of 0.5".

To explore the dust structure of the disk and search for gas, we will observe HD 121191 and HD 121617 at 1.3mm continuum and at the J=2-1 line of different CO isotopologues. In BAND6 the continuum and the selected CO lines can be measured in one Science Goal. In the course of a preparatory work we attempted to predict both the 1.3mm continuum flux density of the disks and the 12CO line profile that comes from 3x10^-5 M_Earth gas orbiting the stars (we assumed a linewidth of 10km/s, corresponding to the average linewidth of the detected gaseous debris disks). We derived both the sensitivity needed to measure the expected continuum with an SNR of 5 and the sensitivity necessary to detect the line peak with an SNR of 4. Since in this case the line detection at HD 121191 required the highest sensitivity, we computed the sensitivity requirements based on its line model.

We will measure the CO lines and the continuum in one Science Goal. We will use two FDM spectral windows for the CO line observations. The 2-1 transitions of 13^CO and C^18O lines will be measured in a single baseband with the coarsest channel spacing of 976.6kHz (1.33km/s). The 12^CO line will be observed in another FDM window with a channel spacing of 244.14kHz (~0.32 km/s). Since these disks have never been spatially resolved therefore we cannot reliably estimate the shape and width of the possible CO spectral line (in the course of sensitivity estimates we assumed a linewidth of 10km/s). The requested 0.32 km/s velocity resolution enable us to resolve the line and study the gas kinematics even in disk orientation close to face-on, when the line width would be ~2-3 km/s. For the continuum observation, we define two wide bandwidth TDM spectral windows, giving a 3.75 GHz total bandwidth. The line free regions of the FDM observations will also be added to the continuum data increasing the aggregate bandwidth to ~6.09GHz in total.

Based on our models we predicted a disk size of ~0.5 and 1.8 arcsec for HD 143675 and HD 145880, respectively (see Preparatory work). We request a spatial resoltuion of 0.8 arcsec for these targets. In the case of HD 143675 we primarily focus on gas detection and do not plan to resolve the sources. We expect a quite high continuum flux of ~1.2 mJy for HD 145880 allowing a good signal-to-noise detection even if the emission is distributed in 4 beams.

To explore the dust structure of the disk and search for gas, we will observe HD 143675 and HD 145880 at 1.3mm continuum and at the J=2-1 line of different CO isotopologues. In BAND6 the continuum and the selected CO lines can be measured in one Science Goal. In the course of a preparatory work we attempted to predict both the 1.3mm continuum flux density of the disks and the 12CO line profile that comes from 3x10^-5 M_Earth gas orbiting the stars (we assumed a linewidth of 10km/s, corresponding to the average linewidth of the detected gaseous debris disks). We derived both the sensitivity needed to measure the expected continuum with an SNR of 5 and the sensitivity necessary to detect the line peak with an SNR of 4. Since in this case the line detection at HD 143675 required the highest sensitivity, we computed the sensitivity requirements based on its line model.

The data rate is high in this setup, but to fulfill our scientific aims we need to observe all three lines whose distances in frequency means that they can only be observed in two different basebands.

We will measure the CO lines and the continuum in one Science Goal. We will use two FDM spectral windows for the CO line observations. The 2-1 transitions of 13^CO and C^18O lines will be measured in a single baseband with the coarsest channel spacing of 976.6kHz (1.33km/s). The 12^CO line will be observed in another FDM window with a channel spacing of 244.14kHz (~0.32 km/s). Since these disks have never been spatially resolved therefore we cannot reliably estimate the shape and width of the possible CO spectral lines (in the course of sensitivity estimates we assumed a linewidth of 10km/s). The requested 0.32 km/s velocity resolution enable us to resolve the line and study the gas kinematics even in disk orientation close to face-on, when the line width would be ~2-3 km/s. For the continuum observation, we define two wide bandwidth TDM spectral windows, giving a 3.75 GHz total bandwidth. The line free regions of the FDM observations will also be added to the continuum data increasing the aggregate bandwidth to ~6.09GHz in total.

The data rate is high in this setup, but to fulfill our scientific aims we need to observe all three lines whose distances in frequency means that they can only be observed in two different basebands.

Based on our models we predicted a disk size of ~0.5 and 0.9 arcsec for HD 98363 and HD 109832, respectively (see Preparatory work). Here we primarily focus on gas detection and do not plan to resolve the sources. Thus we select a spatial resolution (0.8") roughly corresponding to the expected disk sizes.

To measure the dust content and to search for gas in the disk, we will observe HD 98363 and HD 109832 at 1.3mm continuum and at the J=2-1 line of different CO isotopologues. In BAND6 the continuum and the selected CO lines can be measured in one Science Goal. In the course of a preparatory work we attempted to predict both the 1.3mm continuum flux density of the disks and the 12CO line profile that comes from 3x10^-5 M_Earth gas orbiting the stars (we assumed a linewidth of 10km/s, corresponding to the average linewidth of the detected gaseous debris disks). We derived both the sensitivity needed to measure the expected continuum with an SNR of 5 and the sensitivity necessary to detect the line peak with an SNR of 4. Since in this case the line detection at HD 98363 required the highest sensitivity, we computed the sensitivity requirements based on its line model.

We will measure the CO lines and the continuum in one Science Goal. We will use two FDM spectral windows for the CO line observations. The 2-1 transitions of 13^CO and C^18O lines will be measured in a single baseband with the coarsest channel spacing of 976.6kHz (1.33km/s). The 12^CO line will be observed in another FDM window with a channel spacing of 244.14kHz (~0.32 km/s). The expected line profile was computed by assuming that the gas and dust are co-located. The requested 0.32 km/s velocity resolution enabling us to resolve the expected 7.5 km/s broad line into 22 channels. For the continuum observation, we define two wide bandwidth TDM spectral windows, giving a 3.75 GHz total bandwidth. The line free regions of the FDM observations will also be added to the continuum data increasing the aggregate bandwidth to ~6.09 GHz in total.

The data rate is high in this setup, but to fulfill our scientific aims we need to observe all three lines whose distances in frequency means that they can only be observed in two different basebands.

The disk around HD 138965 was successfully resolved at 100um. The disk size is ~4.5 arcsec, the disk inclination is ~58 deg. In order to resolve the disk structure in 3 beams across its major axis we request a spatial resolution of ~1.5 arcsec in our observation, thus, the C36-2 configuration would be ideal for us. The maximum angular scale in this configuration is 11.0 arcsec, significantly larger than the expected disk size, meaning that flux loss due to the missing short spacings poses no major problem. Thus we do not request additional ACA observations in agreement with the suggestions of the Observing Tool.

To explore the dust structure of the disk and search for gas, we will observe HD 138965 at 1.3mm continuum and at the J=2-1 line of different CO isotopologues. In BAND6 the continuum and the selected CO lines can be measured in one Science Goal. In the course of a preparatory work we predicted both the 1.3mm continuum flux density of the disk and a 12CO line profile that comes from 3x10^-5 M_Earth gas orbiting the star. The line profile was computed by assuming that the gas and dust are co-located. We derived both the sensitivity needed to measure the expected continuum with an SNR of 5 and the sensitivity necessary to detect the line peak with an SNR of 4. Since in this case the line detection required a higher sensitivity, we computed the sensitivity requirements based on the line model.

We will measure the CO lines and the continuum in one Science Goal. We will use two FDM spectral windows for the CO line observations. The 2-1 transitions of 13^CO and C^18O lines will be measured in a single baseband with the coarsest channel spacing of 976.6kHz (1.33km/s). The 12^CO line will be observed in another FDM window with a channel spacing of 244.14kHz (~0.32 km/s). The expected line profile was computed by assuming that the gas and dust are co-located. The requested 0.32 km/s velocity resolution enabling us to resolve the expected 12 km/s broad line into 36 channels. For the continuum observation, we define two wide bandwidth TDM spectral windows, giving a 3.75 GHz total bandwidth. The line free regions of the FDM observations will also be added to the continuum data increasing the aggregate bandwidth to ~6.09 GHz in total.

The data rate is high in this setup, but to fulfill our scientific aims we need to observe all three lines whose distances in frequency means that they can only be observed in two different basebands.

The disk around HD 32297 was successfully resolved at shorter wavelengths. The disk size is ~2.1 arcsec, the disk inclination is ~88 deg. In order to resolve the disk structure in 4 beams across its major axis we request a spatial resolution of ~0.5 arcsec in our observation, thus, the C36-3 configuration would be ideal for us. The maximum angular scale in this configuration is 10.9 arcsec, significantly larger than the expected disk size, meaning that flux loss due to the missing short spacings poses no major problem. Thus we do not request additional ACA observations in agreement with the suggestions of the Observing Tool.

To explore the dust structure of the disk and search for gas, we will observe HD 32297 at 1.3mm continuum and at the J=2-1 line of different CO isotopologues. In BAND6 the continuum and the selected CO lines can be measured in one Science Goal. In the course of a preparatory work we predicted both the 1.3mm continuum flux density of the disk and a 12CO line profile that comes from 3x10^-5 M_Earth gas orbiting the star. The line profile was computed by assuming that the gas and dust are co-located. We derived both the sensitivity needed to measure the expected continuum with an SNR of 5 and the sensitivity necessary to detect the line peak with an SNR of 5. Since in this case the line detection required a higher sensitivity, we computed the sensitivity requirements based on the line model.

We will measure the CO lines and the continuum in one Science Goal. We will use two FDM spectral windows for the CO line observations. The 2-1 transitions of 13^CO and C^18O lines will be measured in a single baseband with the coarsest channel spacing of 976.6kHz (1.33km/s). The 12^CO line will be observed in another FDM window with a channel spacing of 244.14kHz (~0.32 km/s). The expected line profile was computed by assuming that the gas and dust are co-located. The requested 0.32 km/s velocity resolution enabling us to resolve the expected 12 km/s broad line into 36 channels. For the continuum observation, we define two wide bandwidth TDM spectral windows, giving a 3.75 GHz total bandwidth. The line free regions of the FDM observations will also be added to the continuum data increasing the aggregate bandwidth to ~6.09 GHz in total.

The disk around HR 4796 was successfully resolved at shorter wavelengths. The disk size is ~2.2 arcsec, the disk inclination is ~77 deg. In order to resolve the disk structure in 7 beams across its major axis we request a spatial resolution of ~0.3 arcsec in our observation, thus, the C36-4 configuration would be ideal for us. The maximum angular scale in this configuration is 4.2 arcsec, significantly larger than the expected disk size, meaning that flux loss due to the missing short spacings poses no major problem. Thus we do not request additional ACA observations in agreement with the suggestions of the Observing Tool.

To explore the dust structure of the disk and search for gas, we will observe HR 4796 at 1.3mm continuum and at the J=2-1 line of different CO isotopologues. In BAND6 the continuum and the selected CO lines can be measured in one Science Goal. In the course of a preparatory work we predicted both the 1.3mm continuum flux density of the disk and a 12CO line profile that comes from 3x10^-5 M_Earth gas orbiting the star. The line profile was computed by assuming that the gas and dust are co-located. We derived both the sensitivity needed to measure the expected continuum with an SNR of 5 and the sensitivity necessary to detect the line peak with an SNR of 5. Since in this case the line detection required a higher sensitivity, we computed the sensitivity requirements based on the line model.

The data rate is high in this setup, but to fulfill our scientific aims we need to observe all three lines whose distances in frequency means that they can only be observed in two different basebands.

We will measure the CO lines and the continuum in one Science Goal. We will use two FDM spectral windows for the CO line observations. The 2-1 transitions of 13^CO and C^18O lines will be measured in a single baseband with the coarsest channel spacing of 976.6kHz (1.33km/s). The 12^CO line will be observed in another FDM window with a channel spacing of 244.14kHz (~0.32 km/s). Since this disk has never been spatially resolved therefore we cannot reliably estimate the shape and width of the possible CO spectral line (in the course of sensitivity estimates we assumed a linewidth of 10km/s). The requested 0.32 km/s velocity resolution enable us to resolve the line and study the gas kinematics even in disk orientation close to face-on, when the line width would be ~2-3 km/s. For the continuum observation, we define two wide bandwidth TDM spectral windows, giving a 3.75 GHz total bandwidth. The line free regions of the FDM observations will also be added to the continuum data increasing the aggregate bandwidth to ~6.09GHz in total.

The data rate is high in this setup, but to fulfill our scientific aims we need to observe all three lines whose distances in frequency means that they can only be observed in two different basebands.

Based on our models we predicted a disk size of ~1.2 arcsec for this source (see Preparatory work). Here we primarily focus on gas detection and do not plan to resolve the source. Thus we select a spatial resolution (1.5") corresponding to the expected disk size.

To measure the dust content and to search for gas in the disk, we will observe HD 118379 at 1.3mm continuum and at the J=2-1 line of different CO isotopologues. In BAND6 the continuum and the selected CO lines can be measured in one Science Goal. In the course of a preparatory work we attempted to predict both the 1.3mm continuum flux density of the disk and the 12CO line profile that comes from 3x10^-5 M_Earth gas orbiting the star (we assumed a linewidth of 10km/s, corresponding to the average linewidth of the detected gaseous debris disks). We derived both the sensitivity needed to measure the expected continuum with an SNR of 5 and the sensitivity necessary to detect the line peak with an SNR of 4. Since in this case the continuum detection required a higher sensitivity, we computed the sensitivity requirements based on the continuum model.

We will measure the CO lines and the continuum in one Science Goal. We will use two FDM spectral windows for the CO line observations. The 2-1 transitions of 13^CO and C^18O lines will be measured in a single baseband with the coarsest channel spacing of 976.6kHz (1.33km/s). The 12^CO line will be observed in another FDM window with a channel spacing of 244.14kHz (~0.32 km/s). Since this disk has never been spatially resolved therefore we cannot reliably estimate the shape and width of the possible CO spectral line (in the course of sensitivity estimates we assumed a linewidth of 10km/s). The requested 0.32 km/s velocity resolution enable us to resolve the line and study the gas kinematics even in disk orientation close to face-on, when the line width would be ~2-3 km/s. For the continuum observation, we define two wide bandwidth TDM spectral windows, giving a 3.75 GHz total bandwidth. The line free regions of the FDM observations will also be added to the continuum data increasing the aggregate bandwidth to ~6.09GHz in total.

The data rate is high in this setup, but to fulfill our scientific aims we need to observe all three lines whose distances in frequency means that they can only be observed in two different basebands.

Based on our models we predicted a disk size of ~3.4 arcsec for this source (see Preparatory work). Since we expect a quite high continuum flux of ~3.2 mJy therefore we request a spatial resolution of 1.5 arcsec with which we will resolve the disk.

To explore the dust structure of the disk and search for gas, we will observe HD 126062 at 1.3mm continuum and at the J=2-1 line of different CO isotopologues. In BAND6 the continuum and the selected CO lines can be measured in one Science Goal. In the course of a preparatory work we attempted to predict both the 1.3mm continuum flux density of the disk and the 12CO line profile that comes from 3x10^-5 M_Earth gas orbiting the star (we assumed a linewidth of 10km/s, corresponding to the average linewidth of the detected gaseous debris disks). We derived both the sensitivity needed to measure the expected continuum with an SNR of 5 and the sensitivity necessary to detect the line peak with an SNR of 4. Since in this case the line detection required a higher sensitivity, we computed the sensitivity requirements based on the line model.

We will measure the CO lines and the continuum in one Science Goal. We will use two FDM spectral windows for the CO line observations. The 2-1 transitions of 13^CO and C^18O lines will be measured in a single baseband with the coarsest channel spacing of 976.6kHz (1.33km/s). The 12^CO line will be observed in another FDM window with a channel spacing of 244.14kHz (~0.32 km/s). Since this disk has never been spatially resolved therefore we cannot reliably estimate the shape and width of the possible CO spectral line (in the course of sensitivity estimates we assumed a linewidth of 10km/s). The requested 0.32 km/s velocity resolution enable us to resolve the line and study the gas kinematics even in disk orientation close to face-on, when the line width would be ~2-3 km/s. For the continuum observation, we define two wide bandwidth TDM spectral windows, giving a 3.75 GHz total bandwidth. The line free regions of the FDM observations will also be added to the continuum data increasing the aggregate bandwidth to ~6.09GHz in total.

The data rate is high in this setup, but to fulfill our scientific aims we need to observe all three lines whose distances in frequency means that they can only be observed in two different basebands.

Based on our models we predicted a disk size of ~0.8 arcsec for this source (see Preparatory work). Since we expect a quite high continuum flux of ~1.1 mJy therefore we request a spatial resolution of 0.5 arcsec with which we will resolve the disk. HD 131488 is our most distant object, where we expect only a very weak line for our minimum CO mass requirements. Usage of even higher spatial resolution would risk the line detection.

To explore the dust structure of the disk and search for gas, we will observe HD 131488 at 1.3mm continuum and at the J=2-1 line of different CO isotopologues. In BAND6 the continuum and the selected CO lines can be measured in one Science Goal. In the course of a preparatory work we attempted to predict both the 1.3mm continuum flux density of the disk and the 12CO line profile that comes from 3x10^-5 M_Earth gas orbiting the star (we assumed a linewidth of 10km/s, corresponding to the average linewidth of the detected gaseous debris disks). We derived both the sensitivity needed to measure the expected continuum with an SNR of 5 and the sensitivity necessary to detect the line peak with an SNR of 4. Since in this case the line detection required a higher sensitivity, we computed the sensitivity requirements based on the line model.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: According to the current paradigm of circumstellar disk evolution, gas-rich primordial disks evolve into gas-poor debris disks composed of second-generation dust. The transition between these phases is little understood. Recently, a measurable amount of gas was found in a few bright debris disks around A-type stars. The origin of gas in most of these systems is thought to be secondary. Nevertheless, we know at least two systems that harbor huge amounts of primordial gas. The existence of gas in debris disks has an important impact on disk evolution models and the timescales for giant planet formation. Here we propose an ALMA survey for the brightest and most massive debris disks around young A-type members of nearby moving groups and associations. By observing their 1.3 mm continuum emission and J=2-1 line of 12CO, 13CO, and C18O, we will measure their dust/gas content and study the dust/gas morphology. Using these results we will 1) decide whether the gas is primordial or secondary; 2) determine the incidence of different types of gaseous debris disks around young A-type stars; 3) analyze the production and evolution of secondary gas in young debris disks.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Circumstellar disks, exoplanets and the solar system

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Faculty of Physics, Valparaiso, University of
